Award.AwardTitle: RI: Medium: Collaborative Research: Decision-Making on Uncertain Spatial-Temporal Fields: Modeling, Planning and Control with Applications to Adaptive Sampling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Inland bodies of freshwater are a resource that is critical for the Nation's health and safety. This project is developing a new spatio-temporal field representation suitable for modeling, planning and control under uncertainty in order to improve monitoring of such water systems. The project's focus is on a reconfigurable aquatic sensor-actuator network designed to capture data from coupled physical, chemical, and biological processes that occur across space and time-scales. The key advantages of this sensor-actuator network in its application to this domain include synoptic volume coverage, adaptive sampling, flexible control and robustness to component failure. The research objective is to build models of dynamic processes for which high resolution sampling is necessary at special locations. Toward this end, this project is contributing new methods, data-structures, algorithms, and implementations validated by field testing a heterogeneous system consisting of stationary and mobile (robotic) underwater node.

This project provides unique interdisciplinary opportunities for education of both graduate and undergraduate students via new course work that blends projects and research topics directly into courses and newly developed seminars. It provides a multi-disciplinary experience for students while developing their engineering skills. Relevant components of computer science, computer engineering, and mechanical engineering are integrated together by using the project's aquatic platform and experimental scenarios as a focal point.

The project advances the state-of-the-art for such systems because it integrates low-level dynamic processes with high-level planning and distributed optimization. The research represents a change in the scale of robotic aquatic sampling away from immense bodies of water in oceanographic research, toward bodies of water that have a more immediate affect on our well-being as they are sources and stores of drinking water. The impact of datasets which lead to better understanding of managed and natural inlets, differing topography including dam walls and man-made structures, regions of turbulence, and seasonal algal growth are immense.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the investigator and several students to study and improve robotic vehicles for deployment in fresh-water marine settings, like lakes and rivers, as we are interested in how such bodies change over time. In particular, our focus in this project was in how multiple robots could coordinate their efforts to do this effectively. We developed new algorithms and models for such systems, and took a robot out in Lake Pleasant, AZ, to sample water quality. During that time we learned several new lessons about the challenge of such operations: after almost losing the robot when it was operating in autonomous mode, we resorted to the commonly used technique of affixing a tether line to the vehicle. Influenced by this experience, the later parts of the project then explored how a tether alters the feasible motions of a robot, and included the development of algorithms and data structures that allow for efficient reasoning by the robot. We also studied several ways robots could represent and reason about the tasks they need to perform so that the process of dividing the labor between the robots could be done efficiently. 

One of the challenges in operating with the vehicle underwater is that communication is unreliable: part of our work dealt with how robots can decide what they should do when they realize something has changed, should they tell others, or is the change too unimportant to be of any significance for the team? It was precisely this question we studied in a paper entitled "When to Do Your Own Thing: Analysis of Cost Uncertainties in Multi-Robot Task Allocation at Run-Time" It is possible that this sort of analysis could be useful more broadly as well, like in automated warehouses and even large teams of self-driving taxis.

Another important question we studied is how marine robots can use information about the structure of their surroundings to help them navigate. In the future, robotic vehicles will do more than move around large bodies of water like lakes or oceans. There is a lot that is interesting in rivers and streams as well: they are sites of ecological diversity—including unique fauna and flora; and, because they are corridors of commerce, several rivers are
of especial historical and cultural significance. Though we often think of rivers as straight bodies of water, they actually seldom flow in straight lines. The physics of water flow induces a sort of structure. That is structure that robots navigating along a river can use to help them anticipate the flow of the unseen portion of the river. The supporting figure shows a robot using knowledge of the snaking shape to have an informed idea of the water lying ahead. In the figure the blue shows the part of the river that the robot has seen, the yellow is where the river lies, and the black lines show different estimates of the (yet unseen) yellow, the darker lines represent estimates with higher weight. You can clearly see how more data gives the robot a better estimate of what is around the next bend.
